Award.AwardTitle: CBET Energy Storage Workshop: Frontiers of Materials, Architectures and Techniques

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the organization of a workshop on Energy Storage: Frontiers of Materials, Architectures, and Techniques. The workshop will be held in the Reno, NV/Lake Tahoe, CA area in March 2020, and it is expected that there will be about 150 attendees. The workshop will take place over one-and-a-half days and will include interactive sessions and a poster session to explore and define current critical "Big Science Questions" in electrochemical energy storage. The energy content of commercial lithium ion battery systems has been increasing in an incremental, evolutionary manner. To achieve break-out advances, new paradigms are required that are separate from established technologies such as ceramic high energy cathodes and graphite-based anodes electrodes. These new component improvements will enable higher performance energy storage systems that help increase the capacity of intermittent renewable energy electricity generation by solar and wind and increase the performance of electric and hybrid electric vehicles.

The workshop has eight planned topic sessions so that all the participants will have the opportunity to contribute their views on key future research directions. The structure will use a Topic Chair, invited speakers, and breakout discussion model for each topic. Topics planned are Industrial Perspectives, Li and Na Metal Batteries, Solid State Electrolyte Batteries, Emerging Li-Ion Cathodes, Hybridized Battery-Capacitors and Fast-Charge Systems, Redox Flow Batteries, Nonaqueous Beyond Li Batteries, and Aqueous Beyond Li Batteries. The organization of the workshop is designed so that a diversity of researchers from academia, national laboratories, and industry can participate in a collaborative environment. The workshop will be explicitly structured to attract the widest possible cross-section of individuals with travel grants to support graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and early-career academic investigators. The outcome of the workshop will be a publicly available white paper.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CBET Energy Storage Workshop: Frontiers of Materials, Architectures and Techniques

I. SUMMARY

Objectives of the Project: CBET Energy Storage Workshop: Frontiers of Materials, Architectures and Techniques was a unique interdisciplinary workshop held on August 13-14, 2020. This was a virtual conference that was run by U.T. Austin. The workshop brought together leaders in academia (faculty, students, and post-doctoral scholars), U.S. national laboratories (staff and post-docs) and industry (business and technical) to explore and define the critical “Big Questions” in electrochemical energy storage. There were 16 invited speakers, 6 being female and 10 being male. A total of 162 people attended these presentations, with 53 being academic professors, 94 being undergraduate students, graduate students and post-doc, 5 being industrial researchers, and 10 being government researchers and program managers. The key findings of the workshop were incorporated into a set of recommendations for future directions and programmatic emphasis of NSF CBET Electrochemical Energy Storage Program.

 

Intellectual Merit: This workshop brought together experts from academia, national laboratories and industry to critically discuss emerging topics in electrochemical energy storage science. The aim was to identify the key broad scientific questions, which, if fully understood, will bring about revolutionary rather than evolutionary advances in energy, safety, power, lifetime, and cost of energy storage materials and devices. The invited speakers and breakout session chairs are recognized global experts in their respective fields. The final product is the white paper (this publication) jointly written by the conference organizers meant to guide the future focus of the United States energy storage community. The 1.5-day workshop combined critical viewpoints from industry (startups though large established blue-chip corporations), U.S. national laboratories, and academia. There has not been a comparable workshop in the U.S. in terms of bringing together such diverse and multidisciplinary teams of world-class engineers and scientists to tackle such an important scientific and societal problem.

 

Broader Impact: The energy content of commercial lithium ion battery (LIBs) systems increases in an evolutionary manner by approximately 7% every year. To achieve revolutionary game-changing advances, however, new entirely new paradigms are required that are outside established ceramic high cathodes and predominantly graphite-based anodes. In parallel, emerging stationary applications require a new paradigm in cost effectiveness with transformative approaches to reduce system-level $/kWh. This workshop defined the critical questions and challenges in materials, device architectures, and fundamental science necessary to bring about revolutionary rather than evolutionary advances in energy, safety, power, lifetime, and cost of electrochemical energy storage systems. A key aspect that ensured the overall success of this event was the selection of the speakers and breakout session to insure maximum diversity. The workshop was explicitly structured to attract the widest possible cross-sections of individuals with funds set aside to support Ph.D. students, post-doctoral fellows, early-career academic investigators, and leaders from emerging start-ups who may not be able to attend otherwise. The findings of the workshop were documented as this publicly available document.

 

CBET Energy Storage Workshop: Frontiers of Materials, Architectures and Techniques was a unique interdisciplinary workshop that brought together leaders in academia (faculty, post-doctoral fellows, and graduate students), U.S. scientific agencies (staff and post-doctoral fellows) and industry (business and technical) to explore and define critical “Big Questions” in electrochemical energy storage. One hundred and seventy-eight researchers from academia, industry, and government attended virtually. The key findings of the workshop were incorporated into a set of recommendations for future directions and programmatic emphasis of the NSF CBET Electrochemical Energy Storage Program.

Dates:        August 13-14, 2020.

Location:    Virtual through U.T. Austin
